member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IClusterModuleSettings
member.summary: Settings to control where, when, and how shards are allocated to nodes.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDiskBasedShardAllocationSettings.HighWatermark
member.summary: Controls the high watermark. It defaults to 90%, meaning OpenSearch will attempt to relocate shards to another node if the node disk usage rises above 90%. It can also be set to an absolute byte value (similar to the low watermark) to relocate shards once less than the configured amount of space is available on the node.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDiskBasedShardAllocationSettings.IncludeRelocations
member.summary: Defaults to true, which means that OpenSearch will take into account shards that are currently being relocated to the target node when computing a nodes disk usage. Taking relocating shards' sizes into account may, however, mean that the disk usage for a node is incorrectly estimated on the high side, since the relocation could be 90% complete and a recently retrieved disk usage would include the total size of the relocating shard as well as the space already used by the running relocation.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDiskBasedShardAllocationSettings.LowWatermark
member.summary: Controls the low watermark for disk usage. It defaults to 85%, meaning OpenSearch will not allocate new shards to nodes once they have more than 85% disk used. It can also be set to an absolute byte value (like 500mb) to prevent OpenSearch from allocating shards if less than the configured amount of space is available.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDiskBasedShardAllocationSettings.ThresholdEnabled
member.summary: Defaults to true. Set to false to disable the disk allocation decider.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDiskBasedShardAllocationSettings.UpdateInterval
member.summary: How often OpenSearch should check on disk usage for each node in the cluster. Defaults to 30s.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllocationEnable.All
member.summary: (default) Allows shard allocation for all kinds of shards.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllocationEnable.Primaries
member.summary: Allows shard allocation only for primary shards.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllocationEnable.NewPrimaries
member.summary: Allows shard allocation only for primary shards for new indices.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllocationEnable.None
member.summary: No shard allocations of any kind are allowed for any indices.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllowRebalance.All
member.summary: (default) Always allow rebalancing.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllowRebalance.Primaries
member.summary: Only when all primaries in the cluster are allocated.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.AllowRebalance.Replicas
member.summary: Only when all shards (primaries and replicas) in the cluster are allocated.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RebalanceEnable.All
member.summary: (default) Allows shard balancing for all kinds of shards.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RebalanceEnable.Primaries
member.summary: Allows shard balancing only for primary shards.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RebalanceEnable.Replicas
member.summary: Allows shard balancing only for replica shards.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RebalanceEnable.None
member.summary: No shard balancing of any kind are allowed for any indices.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardAllocationSettings.AllocationEnable
member.summary: Enable or disable allocation for specific kinds of shards, defaults to all

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardAllocationSettings.NodeConcurrentRecoveries
member.summary: How many concurrent shard recoveries are allowed to happen on a node. Defaults to 2.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardAllocationSettings.NodeInitialPrimariesRecoveries
member.summary: While the recovery of replicas happens over the network, the recovery of an unassigned primary after node restart uses data from the local disk. These should be fast so more initial primary recoveries can happen in parallel on the same node. Defaults to 4.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardAllocationSettings.SameShardHost
member.summary: Allows to perform a check to prevent allocation of multiple instances of the same shard on a single host, based on host name and host address. Defaults to false, meaning that no check is performed by default. This setting only applies if multiple nodes are started on the same machine.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardBalancingHeuristicsSettings.BalanceIndex
member.summary: Defines a factor to the number of shards per index allocated on a specific node (float). Defaults to 0.55f. Raising this raises the tendency to equalize the number of shards per index across all nodes in the cluster.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardBalancingHeuristicsSettings.BalanceShard
member.summary: Defines the weight factor for shards allocated on a node (float). Defaults to 0.45f. Raising this raises the tendency to equalize the number of shards across all nodes in the cluster.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardBalancingHeuristicsSettings.BalanceThreshold
member.summary: Minimal optimization value of operations that should be performed (non negative float). Defaults to 1.0f. Raising this will cause the cluster to be less aggressive about optimizing the shard balance

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardRebalancingSettings.AllowRebalance
member.summary: Specify when shard rebalancing is allowed

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardRebalancingSettings.ConcurrentRebalance
member.summary: Allow to control how many concurrent shard rebalances are allowed cluster wide. Defaults to 2.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IShardRebalancingSettings.RebalanceEnable
member.summary: Enable or disable rebalancing for specific kinds of shards

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IndexingBufferSettings
member.summary:
The indexing buffer is used to store newly indexed documents. When it fills up, the documents in the buffer are written to a segment on disk. It is divided between all shards on the node.
The following settings are static and must be configured on every data node in the cluster

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IndexingBufferSettings.IndexBufferSize
member.summary: Accepts either a percentage or a byte size value. It defaults to 10%, meaning that 10% of the total heap allocated to a node will be used as the indexing buffer size.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IndexingBufferSettings.IndexBufferSizeMaximum
member.summary: If the index_buffer_size is specified as a percentage, then this setting can be used to specify an absolute maximum. Defaults to unbounded.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IndexingBufferSettings.IndexBufferSizeMinimum
member.summary: If the index_buffer_size is specified as a percentage, then this setting can be used to specify an absolute minimum. Defaults to 48mb.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IndexingBufferSettings.ShardBufferSizeMinimum
member.summary: Sets a hard lower limit for the memory allocated per shard for its own indexing buffer. Defaults to 4mb.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IIndicesModuleSettings
member.summary: Settings to control where, when, and how shards are allocated to nodes.

member.summary: defaults to true

member.summary: defaults to 2

member.summary: defaults to 40mb

member.summary: Snapshot repository settings for

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IS3Repository
member.summary:
A snapshot repository that stores snapshots in an Amazon S3 bucket
Requires the repository-s3 plugin to be installed on the cluster

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings
member.summary: Snapshot repository settings for

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.BasePath
member.summary: Specifies the path within bucket to repository data. Defaults to value of repositories.s3.base_path or to root directory if not set.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.Bucket
member.summary: The name of the bucket to be used for snapshots. This field is required

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.BufferSize
member.summary: Minimum threshold below which the chunk is uploaded using a single request. Beyond this threshold, the S3 repository will use the AWS Multipart Upload API to split the chunk into several parts, each of buffer_size length, and to upload each part in its own request. Note that setting a buffer size lower than 5mb is not allowed since it will prevent the use of the Multipart API and may result in upload errors. It is also not possible to set a buffer size greater than 5gb as it is the maximum upload size allowed by S3. Defaults to the minimum between 100mb and 5% of the heap size.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.CannedAcl
member.summary: Specify a canned ACL for the S3 bucket. The S3 repository supports all S3 canned ACLs : private, public-read, public-read-write, authenticated-read, log-delivery-write, bucket-owner-read, bucket-owner-full-control. Defaults to private.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.ChunkSize
member.summary: Big files can be broken down into chunks during snapshotting if needed. The chunk size can be specified in bytes or by using size value notation, i.e. 1gb, 10mb, 5kb. Defaults to 1gb.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.Client
member.summary: The name of the s3 client to use to connect to S3. Defaults to default.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.Compress
member.summary: When set to true metadata files are stored in compressed format. This setting doesn't affect index files that are already compressed by default. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.ServerSideEncryption
member.summary: When set to true files are encrypted on server side using AES256 algorithm. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.StorageClass
member.summary: Sets the S3 storage class type for the backup files. Values may be standard, reduced_redundancy, standard_ia. Defaults to standard.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.PathStyleAccess
member.summary: Whether to force the use of the path style access pattern. If `true`, the path style access pattern will be used. If `false`, the access pattern will be automatically determined by the AWS Java SDK used internally by OpenSearch

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.DisableChunkedEncoding
member.summary: Whether chunked encoding should be disabled or not. If false, chunked encoding is enabled and will be used where appropriate. If true, chunked encoding is disabled and will not be used, which may mean that snapshot operations consume more resources and take longer to complete. It should only be set to true if you are using a storage service that does not support chunked encoding. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.ReadOnly
member.summary: Make the repository readonly. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.MaxRestoreBytesPerSecond
member.summary: Throttles per node restore rate. Defaults to 40mb per second.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IS3RepositorySettings.MaxSnapshotBytesPerSecond
member.summary: Throttles per node snapshot rate. Defaults to 40mb per second.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.ISourceOnlyRepository
member.summary: A source repository enables you to create minimal, source-only snapshots that take up to 50% less space on disk. Source only snapshots contain stored fields and index metadata. They do not include index or doc values structures and are not searchable when restored. After restoring a source-only snapshot, you must reindex the data into a new index.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISourceOnlyRepository.DelegateType
member.summary: The type of snapshot repository to delegate to for storage

member.summary: The index settings to ignore as part of the restore operation

member.summary: Whether indices specified that do not exist should be ignored.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.IncludeAliases
member.summary: Whether to include aliases as part of the restore

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.IncludeGlobalState
member.summary: Whether the cluster global state should be included

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.IndexSettings
member.summary: The index settings that should be applied as part of the restore operation. Some settings cannot be changed as part of a restore operation, for example, the number of shards.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.Indices
member.summary: The indices to restore

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.Partial
member.summary:
Allow partial restore for indices that don't have snapshots of all shards available.
By default, the entire restore operation will fail if one or more indices participating in the operation dont have snapshots of all shards available. It can occur if some shards failed to snapshot for example. It is still possible to restore such indices by setting to true. Only successfully snapshotted shards will be restored in this case and all missing shards will be recreated empty.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.RenamePattern
member.summary: A pattern to use to rename restored indices. The pattern can be used to capture parts of the original index name and used within

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRestoreRequest.RenameReplacement
member.summary: A replacement to use to rename restored indices. Used in conjunction with .

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer.Strict(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Applies or removes the `strict` attribute to the contained query and optionally to all child sub-queries.
member.param: When true, it applies the attribute to all child sub-queries.

A query defined using a raw json string.

member.summary: A fuzzy based query that uses similarity based on Levenshtein (edit distance) algorithm. Warning: this query is not very scalable with its default prefix length of 0. In this case, every term will be enumerated and cause an edit score calculation or max_expansions is not set.

member.summary: The match_phrase_prefix is the same as match_phrase, expect it allows for prefix matches on the last term in the text

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.MultiMatch(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.MultiMatchQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.IMultiMatchQuery})
member.summary: The multi_match query builds further on top of the match query by allowing multiple fields to be specified. The idea here is to allow to more easily build a concise match type query over multiple fields instead of using a relatively more expressive query by using multiple match queries within a bool query.

member.summary: Nested query allows to query nested objects / docs (see nested mapping). The query is executed against the nested objects / docs as if they were indexed as separate docs (they are, internally) and resulting in the root parent doc (or parent nested mapping).

member.summary: A thin wrapper allowing fined grained control what should happen if a query is conditionless if you need to fallback to something other than a match_all query

member.summary: A query that can be used to effectively demote results that match a given query. Unlike the "must_not" clause in bool query, this still selects documents that contain undesirable terms, but reduces their overall score.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.Wildcard``1(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{`0,``0}},System.String,System.Nullable{System.Double},OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite,System.String)
member.summary: Matches documents that have fields matching a wildcard expression (not analyzed). Supported wildcards are *, which matches any character sequence (including the empty one), and ?, which matches any single character. Note this query can be slow, as it needs to iterate over many terms. In order to prevent extremely slow wildcard queries, a wildcard term should not start with one of the wildcards * or ?. The wildcard query maps to Lucene WildcardQuery.

Note this query can be slow, as it needs to iterate over many terms. In order to prevent extremely slow wildcard queries, a wildcard term should not start with one of the wildcards * or ?. The wildcard query maps to Lucene WildcardQuery.

member.summary: Matches documents that have fields matching a wildcard expression (not analyzed). Supported wildcards are *, which matches any character sequence (including the empty one), and ?, which matches any single character. Note this query can be slow, as it needs to iterate over many terms. In order to prevent extremely slow wildcard queries, a wildcard term should not start with one of the wildcards * or ?. The wildcard query maps to Lucene WildcardQuery.

member.summary: Matches documents that have fields containing terms with a specified prefix (not analyzed). The prefix query maps to Lucene PrefixQuery.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.Ids(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.IdsQueryDescriptor,OpenSearch.Client.IIdsQuery})
member.summary: Matches documents that only have the provided ids. Note, this filter does not require the _id field to be indexed since it works using the _uid field.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.Intervals(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.IntervalsQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.IIntervalsQuery})
member.summary: Allows fine-grained control over the order and proximity of matching terms. Matching rules are constructed from a small set of definitions, and the rules are then applied to terms from a particular field. The definitions produce sequences of minimal intervals that span terms in a body of text. These intervals can be further combined and filtered by parent sources.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanTerm(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanTermQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanTermQuery})
member.summary: Matches spans containing a term. The span term query maps to Lucene SpanTermQuery.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanFirst(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanFirstQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanFirstQuery})
member.summary: Matches spans near the beginning of a field. The span first query maps to Lucene SpanFirstQuery.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanNear(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanNearQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanNearQuery})
member.summary: Matches spans which are near one another. One can specify slop, the maximum number of intervening unmatched positions, as well as whether matches are required to be in-order. The span near query maps to Lucene SpanNearQuery.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanOr(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanOrQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanOrQuery})
member.summary: Matches the union of its span clauses. The span or query maps to Lucene SpanOrQuery.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanNot(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanNotQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanNotQuery})
member.summary: Removes matches which overlap with another span query. The span not query maps to Lucene SpanNotQuery.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanMultiTerm(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanMultiTermQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanMultiTermQuery})
member.summary: Wrap a multi term query (one of fuzzy, prefix, term range or regexp query) as a span query so it can be nested.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanContaining(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanContainingQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanContainingQuery})
member.summary: Returns matches which enclose another span query. The span containing query maps to Lucene SpanContainingQuery

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanWithin(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanWithinQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanWithinQuery})
member.summary: Returns Matches which are enclosed inside another span query. The span within query maps to Lucene SpanWithinQuery

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.SpanFieldMasking(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.SpanFieldMaskingQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ISpanFieldMaskingQuery})
member.summary: Wraps span queries to allow them to participate in composite single-field Span queries by 'lying' about their search field. That is, the masked span query will function as normal, but the field points back to the set field of the query. This can be used to support queries like SpanNearQuery or SpanOrQuery across different fields, which is not ordinarily permitted.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.Regexp(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.RegexpQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.IRegexpQuery})
member.summary: Allows you to use regular expression term queries. "term queries" means that OpenSearch will apply the regexp to the terms produced by the tokenizer for that field, and not to the original text of the field.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.FunctionScore(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.FunctionScoreQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.IFunctionScoreQuery})
member.summary: The function_score query allows you to modify the score of documents that are retrieved by a query. This can be useful if, for example, a score function is computationally expensive and it is sufficient to compute the score on a filtered set of documents.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.Percolate(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.PercolateQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.IPercolateQuery})
member.summary: Used to match queries stored in an index. The percolate query itself contains the document that will be used as query to match with the stored queries.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.ParentId(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.ParentIdQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.IParentIdQuery})
member.summary: Used to find child documents which belong to a particular parent.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainerDescriptor`1.TermsSet(System.Func{OpenSearch.Client.TermsSetQueryDescriptor{`0},OpenSearch.Client.ITermsSetQuery})
member.summary: Returns any documents that match with at least one or more of the provided terms. The terms are not analyzed and thus must match exactly. The number of terms that must match varies per document and is either controlled by a minimum should match field or computed per document in a minimum should match script.

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.BoolQueryAndExtensions.TryHandleUnmergableBools(OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer,OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer,OpenSearch.Client.IBoolQuery,OpenSearch.Client.IBoolQuery,OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer@)
member.summary: Handles cases where either side is a bool which indicates it can't be merged yet the other side is mergable. A side is considered unmergable if its locked (has important metadata) or has should clauses. Instead of always wrapping these cases in another bool we merge to unmergable side into to others must clause therefor flattening the generated graph

member.name: M:OpenSearch.Client.BoolQueryAndExtensions.TryHandleBoolsWithOnlyShouldClauses(OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer,OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer,OpenSearch.Client.IBoolQuery,OpenSearch.Client.IBoolQuery,OpenSearch.Client.QueryContainer@)
member.summary: Both Sides are bools, but one of them has only should clauses so we should wrap into a new container. Unless we know one of the sides is a bool with only a must who's clauses are all bools with only shoulds. This is a piece of metadata we set at the bools creation time so we do not have to itterate the clauses on each combination In this case we can optimize the generated graph by merging and preventing stack overflows

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IQuery.Boost
member.summary: Provides a boost to this query to influence its relevance score. For example, a query with a boost of 2 is twice as important as a query with a boost of 1, although the actual boost value that is applied undergoes normalization and internal optimization.
member.remarks: Setting a boost for an query will throw a parsing exception on the server.

member.summary: An array of rules to combine. All rules must produce a match in a document for the overall source to match.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IIntervalsAllOf.MaxGaps
member.summary: Specify a maximum number of gaps between the terms in the text. Terms that appear further apart than this will not match. If unspecified, or set to -1, then there is no width restriction on the match. If set to 0 then the terms must appear next to each other.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IIntervalsFuzzy

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IIntervalsPrefix
member.summary: Matches terms that start with a specified set of characters. This prefix can expand to match at most 128 terms. If the prefix matches more than 128 terms, OpenSearch returns an error. You can use the index-prefixes option in the field mapping to avoid this limit.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IIntervalsQuery
member.summary: A query that allows fine-grained control over the order and proximity of matching terms. Matching rules are constructed from a small set of definitions, and the rules are then applied to terms from a particular field. The definitions produce sequences of minimal intervals that span terms in a body of text. These intervals can be further combined and filtered by parent sources.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IIntervalsWildcard.Pattern
member.summary:
Wildcard pattern used to find matching terms. Supports two wildcard operators:
?, which matches any single character
*, which can match zero or more characters, including an empty one
Warning: Avoid beginning patterns with * or ?. This can increase the iterations needed to find matching terms and slow search performance.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm
member.summary: Multi term query rewrite method

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm.ConstantScore
member.summary: A rewrite method that performs like constant_score_boolean when there are few matching terms and otherwise visits all matching terms in sequence and marks documents for that term. Matching documents are assigned a constant score equal to the querys boost.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm.ScoringBoolean
member.summary: A rewrite method that first translates each term into a should clause in a boolean query, and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Note that typically such scores are meaningless to the user, and require non-trivial CPU to compute. This rewrite method will hit too many clauses failure if it exceeds the boolean query limit (defaults to 1024).

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm.ConstantScoreBoolean
member.summary: Similar to scoring_boolean except scores are not computed. Instead, each matching document receives a constant score equal to the querys boost. This rewrite method will hit too many clauses failure if it exceeds the boolean query limit (defaults to 1024).

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm.TopTermsN
member.summary: A rewrite method that first translates each term into should clause in boolean query, and keeps the scores as computed by the query. This rewrite method only uses the top scoring terms so it will not overflow boolean max clause count. The N controls the size of the top scoring terms to use.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm.TopTermsBoostN
member.summary: A rewrite method that first translates each term into should clause in boolean query, but the scores are only computed as the boost. This rewrite method only uses the top scoring terms so it will not overflow the boolean max clause count. The N controls the size of the top scoring terms to use.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.RewriteMultiTerm.TopTermsBlendedFreqsN
member.summary: A rewrite method that first translates each term into should clause in boolean query, but all term queries compute scores as if they had the same frequency. In practice the frequency which is used is the maximum frequency of all matching terms. This rewrite method only uses the top scoring terms so it will not overflow boolean max clause count. The N controls the size of the top scoring terms to use.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite
member.summary: Controls how a multi term query such as a wildcard or prefix query, is rewritten.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite.ConstantScore
member.summary: A rewrite method that performs like constant_score_boolean when there are few matching terms and otherwise visits all matching terms in sequence and marks documents for that term. Matching documents are assigned a constant score equal to the querys boost.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite.ConstantScoreBoolean
member.summary: Similar to scoring_boolean except scores are not computed. Instead, each matching document receives a constant score equal to the querys boost. This rewrite method will hit too many clauses failure if it exceeds the boolean query limit (defaults to 1024).

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite.Rewrite
member.summary: The type of multi term rewrite to perform

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite.ScoringBoolean
member.summary: A rewrite method that first translates each term into a should clause in a boolean query, and keeps the scores as computed by the query. Note that typically such scores are meaningless to the user, and require non-trivial CPU to compute. This rewrite method will hit too many clauses failure if it exceeds the boolean query limit (defaults to 1024).

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.MultiTermQueryRewrite.Size
member.summary: The size of the top scoring terms to use

A rewrite method that first translates each term into should clause in boolean query, and keeps the scores as computed by the query. This rewrite method only uses the top scoring terms so it will not overflow boolean max clause count.
controls the size of the top scoring terms to use.

A rewrite method that first translates each term into should clause in boolean query, but the scores are only computed as the boost. This rewrite method only uses the top scoring terms so it will not overflow the boolean max clause count.
controls the size of the top scoring terms to use.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IDistanceFeatureQuery
member.summary: Boosts the relevance score of documents closer to a provided origin date or point. For example, you can use this query to give more weight to documents closer to a certain date or location. You can use the distance_feature query to find the nearest neighbors to a location. You can also use the query in a bool searchs should filter to add boosted relevance scores to the bool querys scores.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDistanceFeatureQuery.Origin
member.summary: Date or point of origin used to calculate distances. If the field value is a date or date_nanos field, the origin value must be a date. Date Math, such as now-1h, is supported. If the field value is a geo_point field, the origin value must be a geopoint.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IDistanceFeatureQuery.Pivot
member.summary: Distance from the origin at which relevance scores receive half of the boost value. If the field value is a date or date_nanos field, the pivot value must be a time unit, such as 1h or 10d. If the field value is a geo_point field, the pivot value must be a distance unit, such as 1km or 12m.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureQuery
member.summary:
A query that only works on rank_feature fields and rank_features fields. Its goal is to boost the score of documents based on the values of numeric features. It is typically put in a should clause of a bool query so that its score is added to the score of the query.
Compared to using function_score or other ways to modify the score, this query has the benefit of being able to efficiently skip non-competitive hits when track_total_hits is not set to true. Speedups may be spectacular.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureFunction
member.summary: A function to boost scores in a rank_feature query, using the values of rank features.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureLogarithmFunction
member.summary: Gives a score that is equal to log(scaling_factor + S) where S is the value of the rank feature and scaling_factor is a configurable scaling factor. Scores are unbounded. This function only supports rank features that have a positive score impact.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureLogarithmFunction.ScalingFactor
member.summary: The scaling factor

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureSaturationFunction
member.summary: Gives a score that is equal to S / (S + pivot) where S is the value of the rank feature and pivot is a configurable pivot value so that the result will be less than 0.5 if S is less than pivot and greater than 0.5 otherwise. Scores are always is (0, 1). If the rank feature has a negative score impact then the function will be computed as pivot / (S + pivot), which decreases when S increases.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureSigmoidFunction
member.summary:
is an extension of saturation which adds a configurable exponent. Scores are computed as S^exp^ / (S^exp^ + pivot^exp^). Like for the saturation function, pivot is the value of S that gives a score of 0.5 and scores are in (0, 1).
exponent must be positive, but is typically in [0.5, 1]. A good value should be computed via training. If you dont have the opportunity to do so, we recommend that you stick to the saturation function instead.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureSigmoidFunction.Exponent
member.summary: The exponent. Must be positive

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IRankFeatureLinearFunction
member.summary:
Gives a score equal to the indexed value of S, where S is the value of the rank feature field.
If a rank feature field is indexed with "positive_score_impact": true, its indexed value is equal to S and rounded to preserve only 9 significant bits for the precision.
If a rank feature field is indexed with "positive_score_impact": false, its indexed value is equal to 1/S and rounded to preserve only 9 significant bits for the precision.

member.summary: Queries documents that contain terms matching a regular expression.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRegexpQuery.Flags
member.summary: Enables optional operators for the regular expression.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IRegexpQuery.MaximumDeterminizedStates
member.summary:
Maximum number of automaton states required for the query. Default is 10000.
OpenSearch uses Apache Lucene internally to parse regular expressions. Lucene converts each regular expression to a finite automaton containing a number of determinized states.
You can use this parameter to prevent that conversion from unintentionally consuming too many resources. You may need to increase this limit to run complex regular expressions.

member.summary: Regular expression for terms you wish to find in the provided field

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Collapse
member.summary:
Allows to collapse search results based on field values. The collapsing is done by selecting only the top sorted document per collapse key. For instance the query below retrieves the best tweet for each user and sorts them by number of likes.
NOTE: The collapsing is applied to the top hits only and does not affect aggregations. You can only collapse to a depth of 2.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Explain
member.summary: Enables explanation for each hit on how its score was computed

member.summary:
BETA: Allows for retrieving a list of document fields in the search response.
This functionality is in beta and is subject to change.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.From
member.summary: The starting from index of the hits to return. Defaults to 0.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Highlight
member.summary: Allow to highlight search results on one or more fields. The implementation uses the either lucene fast-vector-highlighter or highlighter.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.IndicesBoost
member.summary: Allows to configure different boost level per index when searching across more than one indices. This is very handy when hits coming from one index matter more than hits coming from another index (think social graph where each user has an index).

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.MinScore
member.summary: Allows to filter out documents based on a minimum score

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.PointInTime
member.summary:
Search against a dataset frozen at a point-in-time (PIT)
https://opensearch.org/docs/latest/search-plugins/point-in-time/
member.remarks: Supported by OpenSearch servers of version 2.4.0 or greater.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.PostFilter
member.summary: Specify a query to apply to the search hits at the very end of a search request, after aggregations have already been calculated. Useful when both search hits and aggregations will be returned in the response, and a filter should only be applied to the search hits.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Profile
member.summary: The Profile API provides detailed timing information about the execution of individual components in a query. It gives the user insight into how queries are executed at a low level so that the user can understand why certain queries are slow, and take steps to improve their slow queries.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Query
member.summary: Specify the search query to perform

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Rescore
member.summary: Specify one or more queries to use for rescoring

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.ScriptFields
member.summary: Allows to return a script evaluation (based on different fields) for each hit

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.SearchAfter
member.summary: Sort values that can be used to start returning results "after" any document in the result list.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Size
member.summary: The number of hits to return. Defaults to 10.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Slice
member.summary: For scroll queries that return a lot of documents it is possible to split the scroll in multiple slices which can be consumed independently

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Sort
member.summary: Specifies how to sort the search hits

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Source
member.summary:
Specify how the _source field is returned for each search hit.
When true, _source retrieval is enabled (default)
When false, _source retrieval is disabled, and no _source will be returned for each hit
When is specified, fields to include/exclude can be controlled

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Suggest
member.summary: The suggest feature suggests similar looking terms based on a provided text by using a suggester

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.TerminateAfter
member.summary: The maximum number of documents to collect for each shard, upon reaching which the query execution will terminate early. If set, the response will have a boolean field terminated_early to indicate whether the query execution has actually terminated_early.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Timeout
member.summary: A search timeout, bounding the search request to be executed within the specified time value and bail with the hits accumulated up to that point, when expired. Defaults to no timeout.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.TrackScores
member.summary: Make sure we keep calculating score even if we are sorting on a field.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.Version
member.summary: Return a version for each search hit

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISearchRequest.RuntimeFields
member.summary: Specifies runtime fields which exist only as part of the query.

member.summary: Whether specified concrete indices should be ignored when unavailable (missing or closed)

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.SearchRequest.MaxConcurrentShardRequests
member.summary: The number of concurrent shard requests per node this search executes concurrently. This value should be used to limit the impact of the search on the cluster in order to limit the number of concurrent shard requests

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.SearchRequest.PreFilterShardSize
member.summary: A threshold that enforces a pre-filter roundtrip to prefilter search shards based on query rewriting if thenumber of shards the search request expands to exceeds the threshold. This filter roundtrip can limit the number of shards significantly if for instance a shard can not match any documents based on its rewrite method ie. if date filters are mandatory to match but the shard bounds and the query are disjoint.

member.summary: Specify the node or shard the operation should be performed on (default: random)

member.summary: Specify if request cache should be used for this request or not, defaults to index level setting

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.SearchRequest.Routing
member.summary:
A document is routed to a particular shard in an index using the following formula
shard_num = hash(_routing) % num_primary_shards
OpenSearch will use the document id if not provided.
For requests that are constructed from/for a document OSC will automatically infer the routing key if that document has a or a routing mapping on for its type exists on

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IFieldCollapse
member.summary:
Allows to collapse search results based on field values. The collapsing is done by selecting only the top sorted document per collapse key. For instance the query below retrieves the best tweet for each user and sorts them by number of likes.
NOTE: The collapsing is applied to the top hits only and does not affect aggregations.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IFieldCollapse.Field
member.summary: The field used for collapsing must be a single valued keyword or number field with doc-values activated

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IFieldCollapse.InnerHits
member.summary: It is also possible to expand each collapsed top hits with the `inner_hits` option.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IFieldCollapse.MaxConcurrentGroupSearches
member.summary: The expansion of the group is done by sending an additional query for each inner_hit request for each collapsed hit returned in the response. This can significantly slow things down if you have too many groups and/or inner_hit requests. The max_concurrent_group_searches request parameter can be used to control the maximum number of concurrent searches allowed in this phase. The default is based on the number of data nodes and the default search thread pool size.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.BoundaryScanner.Characters
member.summary: (default mode for the FVH): allows to configure which characters (boundary_chars) constitute a boundary for highlighting. Its a single string with each boundary character defined in it (defaults to .,!? \t\n). It also allows configuring the boundary_max_scan to control how far to look for boundary characters (defaults to 20). Works only with the Fast Vector Highlighter.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.BoundaryScanner.Sentence
member.summary: sentence and word: use Javas BreakIterator to break the highlighted fragments at the next sentence or word boundary. You can further specify boundary_scanner_locale to control which Locale is used to search the text for these boundaries.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.BoundaryScanner.Word
member.summary: sentence and word: use Javas BreakIterator to break the highlighted fragments at the next sentence or word boundary. You can further specify boundary_scanner_locale to control which Locale is used to search the text for these boundaries.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.BoundaryChars
member.summary: Defines what constitutes a boundary for highlighting when using the fast vector highlighter. It's a single string with each boundary character defined in it. It defaults to .,!? \t\n.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.BoundaryMaxScan
member.summary: Controls how far to look for boundary characters. Defaults to 20.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.BoundaryScanner
member.summary: When highlighting a field using the unified highlighter or the fast vector highlighter, you can specify how to break the highlighted fragments using boundary_scanner

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.BoundaryScannerLocale
member.summary: You can further specify boundary_scanner_locale to control which Locale is used to search the text for these boundaries.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.Encoder
member.summary: Define how highlighted text will be encoded. It can be either default (no encoding) or html (will escape html, if you use html highlighting tags).

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.Fragmenter
member.summary: Fragmenter can control how text should be broken up in highlight snippets. However, this option is applicable only for the Plain Highlighter

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.FragmentOffset
member.summary: Controls the margin to start highlighting from when using the fast vector highlighter

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.FragmentSize
member.summary: The size of the highlighted fragment, in characters. Defaults to 100

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.HighlightQuery
member.summary: The query to use for highlighting

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.MaxAnalyzerOffset
member.summary: If this setting is set to a non-negative value, the highlighting stops at this defined maximum limit, and the rest of the text is not processed, thus not highlighted and no error is returned.
member.remarks: Introduced in OpenSearch 2.2

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.NoMatchSize
member.summary: In the case where there is no matching fragment to highlight, the default is to not return anything. Instead, we can return a snippet of text from the beginning of the field by setting no_match_size (default 0) to the length of the text that you want returned. The actual length may be shorter or longer than specified as it tries to break on a word boundary.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.NumberOfFragments
member.summary: The maximum number of fragments to return. Defaults to 5.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.Order
member.summary: The order in which highlighted fragments are sorted

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.PostTags
member.summary: Controls the post tag in which to wrap highights. By default, the highlighting will wrap highlighted text in and . Using the fast vector highlighter, there can be more tags, and the importance is ordered.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.PreTags
member.summary: Controls the pre tag in which to wrap highights. By default, the highlighting will wrap highlighted text in and . Using the fast vector highlighter, there can be more tags, and the importance is ordered.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.RequireFieldMatch
member.summary: Use a specific "tag" schemas.
member.remarks: Currently a single schema called "styled" with the following pre_tags: <em class="hlt1">, <em class="hlt2">, <em class="hlt3">, <em class="hlt4">, <em class="hlt5">, <em class="hlt6">, <em class="hlt7">, <em class="hlt8">, <em class="hlt9">, <em class="hlt10">

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlight.TagsSchema
member.summary: Use a specific "tag" schemas.
member.remarks: Currently a single schema called "styled" with the following pre_tags: <em class="hlt1">, <em class="hlt2">, <em class="hlt3">, <em class="hlt4">, <em class="hlt5">, <em class="hlt6">, <em class="hlt7">, <em class="hlt8">, <em class="hlt9">, <em class="hlt10">

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterEncoder.Default

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterEncoder.Html

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterFragmenter
member.summary: Fragmenter can control how text should be broken up in highlight snippets. However, this option is applicable only for the Plain Highlighter

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterFragmenter.Simple
member.summary: Breaks up text into same sized fragments.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterFragmenter.Span
member.summary: Same as the simple fragmenter, but tries not to break up text between highlighted terms (this is applicable when using phrase like queries). This is the default.

member.summary: Sorts highlighted fragments

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterOrder.Score
member.summary: Sorts highlighted fragments by score. Only valid for the highlighter

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterTagsSchema
member.summary: Use a built-in tag schema

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterTagsSchema.Styled
member.summary: Use a specific "tag" schemas.

remarks.para: Currently a single schema called "styled" with the following pre_tags:

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterType
member.summary: Type of highlighter

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterType.Plain
member.summary: Plain Highlighter. Uses the Lucene highlighter. It tries hard to reflect the query matching logic in terms of understanding word importance and any word positioning criteria in phrase queries.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterType.Fvh
member.summary: Fast Vector Highlighter. If term_vector information is provided by setting term_vector to with_positions_offsets in the mapping then the fast vector highlighter will be used instead of the plain highlighter

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.HighlighterType.Unified
member.summary: Unified Highlighter. The default choice. The unified highlighter can extract offsets from either term vectors, or via re-analyzing text. Under the hood it uses Lucene UnifiedHighlighter which picks its strategy depending on the field and the query to highlight. Independently of the strategy this highlighter breaks the text into sentences and scores individual sentences as if they were documents in this corpus, using the BM25 algorithm. It supports accurate phrase and multi-term (fuzzy, prefix, regex) highlighting

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.BoundaryChars
member.summary: Defines what constitutes a boundary for highlighting when using the fast vector highlighter. It's a single string with each boundary character defined in it. It defaults to .,!? \t\n.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.BoundaryMaxScan
member.summary: Controls how far to look for boundary characters. Defaults to 20.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.BoundaryScanner
member.summary: When highlighting a field using the unified highlighter or the fast vector highlighter, you can specify how to break the highlighted fragments using boundary_scanner

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.BoundaryScannerLocale
member.summary: You can further specify boundary_scanner_locale to control which Locale is used to search the text for these boundaries.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.Field
member.summary: The field on which to perform highlighting.
member.remarks: In order to perform highlighting, the actual content of the field is required. If the field in question is stored (has store set to true in the mapping) it will be used, otherwise, the actual _source will be loaded and the relevant field will be extracted from it.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.ForceSource
member.summary: Forces the highlighting to highlight fields based on the source even if fields are stored separately.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.Fragmenter
member.summary: Fragmenter can control how text should be broken up in highlight snippets. However, this option is applicable only for the Plain Highlighter

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.FragmentOffset
member.summary: Controls the margin to start highlighting from when using the fast vector highlighter

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.FragmentSize
member.summary: The size of the highlighted fragment, in characters. Defaults to 100

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.HighlightQuery
member.summary: The query to use for highlighting

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.MatchedFields
member.summary: Combine matches on multiple fields to highlight a single field when using the fast vector highighter. This is most intuitive for multifields that analyze the same string in different ways. All matched fields must have term_vector set to with_positions_offsets, but only the field to which the matches are combined is loaded so only that field would benefit from having store set to yes.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.MaxAnalyzerOffset
member.summary: If this setting is set to a non-negative value, the highlighting stops at this defined maximum limit, and the rest of the text is not processed, thus not highlighted and no error is returned.
member.remarks: Introduced in OpenSearch 2.2

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.NoMatchSize
member.summary: The length of a snippet of text from the beginning of the field to return when no match for highlighting is found. Default behaviour is to not return anything when a match is not found. The actual length may be shorter than specified as it tries to break on a word boundary.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.NumberOfFragments
member.summary: The maximum number of fragments to return. Defaults to 5.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.Order
member.summary: The order in which highlighted fragments are sorted. Only valid for the unified highlighter.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.PhraseLimit
member.summary: Controls the number of matching phrases in a document that are considered. Prevents the highlighter from analyzing too many phrases and consuming too much memory. When using matched_fields, phrases per matched field are considered. Raising the limit increases query time and consumes more memory. Only supported by the highlighter. Defaults to 256.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.PostTags
member.summary: Controls the post tag in which to wrap highights. By default, the highlighting will wrap highlighted text in and . Using the fast vector highlighter, there can be more tags, and the importance is ordered.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.PreTags
member.summary: Controls the pre tag in which to wrap highights. By default, the highlighting will wrap highlighted text in and . Using the fast vector highlighter, there can be more tags, and the importance is ordered.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.RequireFieldMatch
member.summary: Determines if only fields that hold a query match will be highlighted. Set to false will cause any field to be highlighted regardless of whether the query matched specifically on them. Default behaviour is true.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.TagsSchema
member.summary: Use a specific "tag" schemas.
member.remarks: Currently a single schema called "styled" with the following pre_tags: <em class="hlt1">, <em class="hlt2">, <em class="hlt3">, <em class="hlt4">, <em class="hlt5">, <em class="hlt6">, <em class="hlt7">, <em class="hlt8">, <em class="hlt9">, <em class="hlt10">

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IHighlightField.Type
member.summary: The type of highlighter to use. Can be a defined or custom highlighter

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.TotalHits
member.summary: Description of the total number of hits of a query. The total hit count can't generally be computed accurately without visiting all matches, which is costly for queries that match lots of documents. Given that it is often enough to have a lower bounds of the number of hits, such as "there are more than 1000 hits", OpenSearch has options to stop counting as soon as a threshold has been reached in order to improve query times.

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.ICompletionSuggester
member.summary: The completion suggester provides auto-complete/search-as-you-type functionality. This is a navigational feature to guide users to relevant results as they are typing, improving search precision. It is not meant for spell correction or did-you-mean functionality like the term or phrase suggesters.

member.summary: Context mappings used to filter and/or boost suggestions

member.summary: Support fuzziness for the suggestions

member.summary: Prefix as a regular expression used to search for suggestions

member.summary: Whether duplicate suggestions should be filtered out. Defaults to false

member.summary: The fuzziness factor. defaults to AUTO

member.summary: Minimum length of the input before fuzzy suggestions are returned. Defaults to 3

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISuggestFuzziness.Transpositions
member.summary: if set to true, transpositions are counted as one change instead of two. Defaults to true

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ISuggestFuzziness.UnicodeAware
member.summary: If true, all measurements (like fuzzy edit distance, transpositions, and lengths) are measured in Unicode code points instead of in bytes. This is slightly slower than raw bytes, so it is set to false by default.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggestCollate.Prune
member.summary: Controls if all phrase suggestions will be returned. When set to true, the suggestions will have an additional option collate_match, which will be true if matching documents for the phrase was found, false otherwise. The default value for is false.

member.summary: The collate query to run.

member.summary: The id for a stored script to execute

member.summary: The source script to be executed

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester
member.summary: The phrase suggester adds additional logic on top of the term suggester to select entire corrected phrases instead of individual tokens weighted based on ngram-language models. In practice this suggester will be able to make better decisions about which tokens to pick based on co-occurrence and frequencies.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.Collate
member.summary: Checks each suggestion against the specified query to prune suggestions for which no matching docs exist in the index. The collate query for a suggestion is run only on the local shard from which the suggestion has been generated from. The query must be specified and can be templated. The current suggestion is automatically made available as the {{suggestion}} variable, which should be used in your query. You can still specify your own template params, the suggestion value will be added to the variables you specify. Additionally, you can specify a prune to control if all phrase suggestions will be returned; when set to true the suggestions will have an additional option collate_match, which will be true if matching documents for the phrase was found, false otherwise. The default value for prune is false.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.Confidence
member.summary: The confidence level defines a factor applied to the input phrases score which is used as a threshold for other suggest candidates. Only candidates that score higher than the threshold will be included in the result. For instance a confidence level of 1.0 will only return suggestions that score higher than the input phrase. If set to 0.0 the top N candidates are returned. The default is 1.0.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.DirectGenerator
member.summary: Candidate generators used to produce a list of possible terms per term in the given text. A single candidate generator is similar to a term suggester called for each individual term in the text. The output of the generators is subsequently scored in combination with the candidates from the other terms for suggestion candidates. Each of the generators is called per term in the original text.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.GramSize
member.summary: Sets max size of the n-grams (shingles) in the field. If the field doesnt contain n-grams (shingles), this should be omitted or set to 1. Note that OpenSearch tries to detect the gram size based on the specified field. If the field uses a shingle filter, the gram_size is set to the max_shingle_size if not explicitly set.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.Highlight
member.summary: Sets up suggestion highlighting. If not provided then no highlighted field is returned. If provided must contain exactly pre_tag and post_tag, which are wrapped around the changed tokens. If multiple tokens in a row are changed the entire phrase of changed tokens is wrapped rather than each token.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.MaxErrors
member.summary: The maximum percentage of the terms considered to be misspellings in order to form a correction. This method accepts a float value in the range [0..1) as a fraction of the actual query terms or a number >=1 as an absolute number of query terms. The default is set to 1.0, meaning only corrections with at most one misspelled term are returned. Note that setting this too high can negatively impact performance. Low values like 1 or 2 are recommended; otherwise the time spend in suggest calls might exceed the time spend in query execution.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.RealWordErrorLikelihood
member.summary: The likelihood of a term being a misspelled even if the term exists in the dictionary. The default is 0.95, meaning 5% of the real words are misspelled.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.Separator
member.summary: The separator that is used to separate terms in the bigram field. If not set the whitespace character is used as a separator.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.ShardSize
member.summary: Sets the maximum number of suggested terms to be retrieved from each individual shard. During the reduce phase, only the top N suggestions are returned based on the size option. Defaults to 5.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.IPhraseSuggester.Smoothing
member.summary: Smoothing model to balance weight between infrequent grams (grams (shingles) are not existing in the index) and frequent grams (appear at least once in the index).

member.summary: Sets the text / query to provide suggestions for.

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.SuggestSort.Score
member.summary: Sort by score first, then document frequency and then the term itself

member.name: F:OpenSearch.Client.SuggestSort.Frequency
member.summary: Sort by document frequency first, then similarity score and then the term itself

member.name: T:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester
member.summary: The term suggester suggests terms based on edit distance. The provided suggest text is analyzed before terms are suggested. The suggested terms are provided per analyzed suggest text token. The term suggester doesnt take the query into account that is part of request.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.LowercaseTerms
member.summary: Lower cases the suggest text terms after text analysis.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.MaxEdits
member.summary: The maximum edit distance candidate suggestions can have in order to be considered as a suggestion. Can only be a value between 1 and 2. Any other value result in an bad request error being thrown. Defaults to 2.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.MaxInspections
member.summary: A factor that is used to multiply with the shards_size in order to inspect more candidate spell corrections on the shard level. Can improve accuracy at the cost of performance. Defaults to 5.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.MaxTermFrequency
member.summary: The maximum threshold in number of documents a suggest text token can exist in order to be included. Can be a relative percentage number (e.g 0.4) or an absolute number to represent document frequencies. If an value higher than 1 is specified then fractional can not be specified. Defaults to 0.01f. This can be used to exclude high frequency terms from being spellchecked. High frequency terms are usually spelled correctly on top of this also improves the spellcheck performance. The shard level document frequencies are used for this option.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.MinDocFrequency
member.summary: The minimal threshold in number of documents a suggestion should appear in. This can be specified as an absolute number or as a relative percentage of number of documents. This can improve quality by only suggesting high frequency terms. Defaults to 0f and is not enabled. If a value higher than 1 is specified then the number cannot be fractional. The shard level document frequencies are used for this option.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.MinWordLength
member.summary: The minimum length a suggest text term must have in order to be included. Defaults to 4.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.PrefixLength
member.summary: The number of minimal prefix characters that must match in order be a candidate suggestions. Defaults to 1. Increasing this number improves spellcheck performance. Usually misspellings dont occur in the beginning of terms.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.ShardSize
member.summary: Sets the maximum number of suggestions to be retrieved from each individual shard. During the reduce phase only the top N suggestions are returned based on the size option. Defaults to the size option. Setting this to a value higher than the size can be useful in order to get a more accurate document frequency for spelling corrections at the cost of performance. Due to the fact that terms are partitioned amongst shards, the shard level document frequencies of spelling corrections may not be precise. Increasing this will make these document frequencies more precise.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.Sort
member.summary: Defines how suggestions should be sorted per suggest text term

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.StringDistance
member.summary: Which string distance implementation to use for comparing how similar suggested terms are.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.SuggestMode
member.summary: Controls what suggestions are included or controls for what suggest text terms, suggestions should be suggested.

member.name: P:OpenSearch.Client.ITermSuggester.Text
member.summary: The suggest text

member.summary: Gets the explanations if Explain() was set.
